55202.meaning_1: bound with a chain by gratification to the mental representation of form

16485.example_1: So there are six preoccupations with happiness, six preoccupations with sadness, and six preoccupations with equanimity.

16360.meaning_1: grasped; clung to; attached to; taken as mine; taken possession (of)
16360.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, upādiṇṇa refers to the solid, hard elements of the body that are clung to or appropriated as "mine".
16360.example_1: katamā ca, bhikkhu, ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu? yaṃ ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ kakkhaḷaṃ kharigataṃ upādinnaṃ [upādiṇṇaṃ], seyyathidaṃ, kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ [aṭṭhimiñjā] vakkaṃ hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ papphāsaṃ antaṃ antaguṇaṃ udariyaṃ karīsaṃ, yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ kakkhaḷaṃ kharigataṃ upādinnaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu, ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu. yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu yā ca bāhirā pathavīdhātu pathavīdhāturevesā.

56999.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence from MN140, saṅghaṭa refers to the friction created when two sticks are rubbed together, generating heat.
56999.example_1: 357. seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānaṃ saṅghaṭṭā [samphassa, saṅghaṭā] samodhānā usmā jāyati, tejo abhinibbattati, tesaṃyeva dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānaṃ nānābhāvā vikkhepā yā tajjā usmā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammati, evameva kho, bhikkhu, sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhā vedanā. so sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti pajānāti.

83026.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence clearly shows this refers to various types of gold ornaments (bracelet, earrings, necklace, garland), thus confirming the meaning as ornament design.
83026.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, dakkho suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā ukkaṃ bandheyya, ukkaṃ bandhitvā ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpeyya, ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpetvā saṇḍāsena jātarūpaṃ gahetvā ukkāmukhe pakkhipeyya, tamenaṃ kālena kālaṃ abhidhameyya, kālena kālaṃ udakena paripphoseyya, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkheyya, taṃ hoti jātarūpaṃ sudhantaṃ niddhantaṃ nīhaṭaṃ ninnītakasāvaṃ mudu ca kammaññañca pabhassarañca, yassā yassā ca piḷandhanavikatiyā ākaṅkhati—yadi paṭṭikāya yadi kuṇḍalāya yadi gīveyyakāya yadi suvaṇṇamālāya tañcassa atthaṃ anubhoti;
83026.example_1: It’s like when a deft goldsmith or a goldsmith’s apprentice prepares a forge, fires the crucible, picks up some native gold with tongs and puts it in the crucible. From time to time they fan it, from time to time they sprinkle water on it, and from time to time they just watch over it. That native gold becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and is ready to be worked. Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a bracelet, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland.

44804.meaning_1: a kind of ornament; a type of necklace

44804.example_1: athāparaṃ upekkhāyeva avasissati parisuddhā pariyodātā mudu ca kammaññā ca pabhassarā ca. seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, dakkho suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā ukkaṃ bandheyya, ukkaṃ bandhitvā ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpeyya, ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpetvā saṇḍāsena jātarūpaṃ gahetvā ukkāmukhe pakkhipeyya, tamenaṃ kālena kālaṃ abhidhameyya, kālena kālaṃ udakena paripphoseyya, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkheyya, taṃ hoti jātarūpaṃ [jātarūpaṃ dhantaṃ] sudhantaṃ niddhantaṃ nīhaṭaṃ [nihataṃ] ninnītakasāvaṃ [nihatakasāvaṃ] mudu ca kammaññañca pabhassarañca, yassā yassā ca piḷandhanavikatiyā ākaṅkhati, yadi paṭṭikāya [pavaṭṭikāya] yadi kuṇḍalāya yadi gīveyyakāya yadi suvaṇṇamālāya tañcassa atthaṃ anubhoti, evameva kho, bhikkhu, athāparaṃ upekkhāyeva avasissati parisuddhā pariyodātā mudu ca kammaññā ca pabhassarā ca.

4844.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the term refers to the extinguishing of a lamp due to lack of fuel (oil and wick), metaphorically describing the cessation of consciousness.
4844.example_1: 365. seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, telañca paṭicca vaṭṭiñca paṭicca telappadīpo jhāyati, tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā aññassa ca anupahārā [anupāhārā, anupādānā] anāhāro nibbāyati, evameva kho, bhikkhu, kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti pajānāti, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantīti pajānāti. tasmā evaṃ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena paññādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.

6374.meaning_1: whose bowl and (set of) robes are incomplete

49403.example_1: atha kho āyasmā pukkusāti bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pattacīvarapariyesanaṃ pakkāmi. atha kho āyasmantaṃ pukkusātiṃ pattacīvarapariyesanaṃ carantaṃ vibbhantā gāvī [bhantagāvī, gāvī] jīvitā voropesi. atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.

57574.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, sataguṇā describes the expected return (dakkhiṇā) from giving gifts to animals, being one hundred times the value of the gift.
57574.sutta_1: tatrānanda, tiracchānagate dānaṃ datvā sataguṇā dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā, puthujjanadussīle dānaṃ datvā sahassaguṇā dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā, puthujjanasīlavante dānaṃ datvā satasahassaguṇā dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā, bāhirake kāmesu vītarāge dānaṃ datvā koṭisatasahassaguṇā dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā, sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanne dānaṃ datvā asaṅkheyyā appameyyā dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā, ko pana vādo sotāpanne, ko pana vādo sakadāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanne, ko pana vādo sakadāgāmissa, ko pana vādo anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanne, ko pana vādo anāgāmissa, ko pana vādo arahattaphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanne, ko pana vādo arahante, ko pana vādo paccekasambuddhe, ko pana vādo tathāgate arahante sammāsambuddhe.
57574.example_1: Now, Ānanda, gifts to the following persons may be expected to yield the following returns. To an animal, a hundred times. To an unethical ordinary person, a thousand. To an ethical ordinary person, a hundred thousand. To an outsider free of desire for sensual pleasures, 10,000,000,000. But a gift to someone practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry may be expected to yield incalculable, immeasurable returns. How much more so a gift to a stream-enterer, someone practicing to realize the fruit of once-return, a once-returner, someone practicing to realize the fruit of non-return, a non-returner, someone practicing to realize the fruit of perfection, a perfected one, or an independent Buddha? How much more so a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha?

9545.meaning_1: having not uprooted; having not eradicated; having not exterminated; having not utterly destroyed
9545.construction:
na > a + saṃ + ud > ū + √han + itvā
na + samūhanitvā
9545.phonetic:
ṃu > mu
ud > ū before h
9545.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, asamūhanitvā refers to not eradicating the underlying tendency of ignorance in neutral feeling, which prevents the cessation of suffering.
9545.sutta_1: so vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṃ appahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṃ appaṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṃ asamūhanitvā avijjaṃ appahāya vijjaṃ anuppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
9545.example_1: Mendicants, without giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, without dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, without eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, without giving up ignorance and without giving rise to knowledge, it is quite impossible to make an end of suffering in this very life.

35428.example_1: evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena nagaravindaṃ nāma kosalānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ gāmo tadavasari. assosuṃ kho nagaravindeyyakā [nagaravindeyyā] brāhmaṇagahapatikā, samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ nagaravindaṃ anuppatto. taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato, itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

59515.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, samavisamaṃ describes the uneven conduct of ascetics who are not free from defilements, acting inconsistently in body, speech, and mind.
59515.sutta_1: ‘ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu avītarāgā avītadosā avītamohā, ajjhattaṃ avūpasantacittā, samavisamaṃ caranti kāyena vācāya manasā, evarūpā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na sakkātabbā na garukātabbā na mānetabbā na pūjetabbā.
59515.example_1: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are not free of greed, hate, and delusion for sights known by the eye, who are not peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves badly among the good by way of body, speech, and mind. They don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.

54831.meaning_1: removal of lust; dispelling of desire
54831.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, rāgavinayāya refers to the practice of removing lust, paired with similar terms for removing hate (dosavinayāya) and delusion (mohavinayāya).
54831.sutta_1: addhā te āyasmanto vītarāgā vā rāgavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītadosā vā dosavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītamohā vā mohavinayāya vā paṭipannā’ti?
54831.example_1: “Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”?’

34248.meaning_1: removal of aversion; dispelling of ill-will
34248.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, dosavinayāya refers to the practice of removing ill-will, paired with vītadosā (free from hatred) showing the goal of this practice.
34248.sutta_1: addhā te āyasmanto vītarāgā vā rāgavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītadosā vā dosavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītamohā vā mohavinayāya vā paṭipannā’ti?
34248.example_1: “Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”?’

53418.meaning_1: removal of illusion; dispelling of delusion
53418.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, mohavinayāya refers to the practice of removing delusion, parallel to removing greed (rāga) and hate (dosa).
53418.sutta_1: addhā te āyasmanto vītarāgā vā rāgavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītadosā vā dosavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītamohā vā mohavinayāya vā paṭipannā’ti?
53418.example_1: “Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”?’

46053.meaning_1: Discourse on the Purification of Almsfood
46053.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The sutta discusses the proper attitude and purity regarding almsfood, as indicated by its title and context in MN 151

40256.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, paṭikkami refers to the act of returning from alms-round, showing the basic meaning of "going back" from a location.
40256.sutta_1: ‘yena cāhaṃ maggena gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ, yasmiñca padese piṇḍāya acariṃ, yena ca maggena gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamiṃ, atthi nu kho me tattha cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu chando vā rāgo vā doso vā moho vā paṭighaṃ vāpi cetaso’ti?
40256.example_1: ‘Along the path that I went for alms, or in the place I wandered for alms, or along the path that I returned from alms, was there any desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion in my heart for sights known by the eye?’

13755.meaning_1: The Discourse on the Development of the Faculties
13755.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The title refers to MN 152, which discusses the development and mastery of the spiritual faculties (indriya)

24055.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The town is mentioned in MN 152 as a location where the Buddha stayed. The name appears to be derived from "jaṅgala" meaning wilderness or uncultivated land, possibly with the prefix "ku" (bad) or "go" (cow).
24055.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gajaṅgalāyaṃ viharati suveḷuvane.
24055.example_1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kajaṅgalā in a bamboo grove.

19294.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The town is mentioned in MN152 as a place where the Buddha stayed. Variant readings include gajaṅgalāyaṃ and kajaṅgalāyaṃ.
19294.example_1: 453. evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gajaṅgalāyaṃ [kajaṅgalāyaṃ, kajjaṅgalāyaṃ] viharati suveḷuvane [veḷuvane, mukheluvane] . atha kho uttaro māṇavo pārāsiviyantevāsī [pārāsariyantevāsī, pārāsiriyantevāsī] yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.

64644.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this refers specifically to a bamboo grove near Kajaṅgalā where the Buddha stayed.
64644.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gajaṅgalāyaṃ viharati suveḷuvane.
64644.example_1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kajaṅgalā in a bamboo grove.

52804.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this as an alternative reading for suveḷuvane, suggesting it may be a variant name for the same location.
52804.example_1: 453. evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gajaṅgalāyaṃ [kajaṅgalāyaṃ, kajjaṅgalāyaṃ] viharati suveḷuvane [veḷuvane, mukheluvane] . atha kho uttaro māṇavo pārāsiviyantevāsī [pārāsariyantevāsī, pārāsiriyantevāsī] yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.

45781.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this term referring to Uttara, a student of Pārāsiviya, being addressed by the Buddha.
45781.sutta_1: sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho uttaraṃ māṇavaṃ pārāsiviyantevāsiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
45781.example_1: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

45778.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this term being used to describe a young brahmin student (Uttaro māṇavo) who approaches the Buddha. The compound follows the common pattern of [teacher] + antevāsī seen in other occupational apprentice terms.
45778.example_1: evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gajaṅgalāyaṃ [kajaṅgalāyaṃ, kajjaṅgalāyaṃ] viharati suveḷuvane [veḷuvane, mukheluvane] . atha kho uttaro māṇavo pārāsiviyantevāsī [pārāsariyantevāsī, pārāsiriyantevāsī] yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.

45779.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this term referring to a student of Pārāsiriya, a teacher mentioned in MN152.
45779.example_1: evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gajaṅgalāyaṃ [kajaṅgalāyaṃ, kajjaṅgalāyaṃ] viharati suveḷuvane [veḷuvane, mukheluvane] . atha kho uttaro māṇavo pārāsiviyantevāsī [pārāsariyantevāsī, pārāsiriyantevāsī] yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.

45780.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this as the name of a Brahman teacher who taught the development of faculties to his disciples.
45780.example_1: “Uttara, does Pārāsariya teach his disciples the development of the faculties?”

18193.meaning_1: just as quickly; so swiftly; as rapidly as this
18193.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, evaṃsīghaṃ emphasizes the remarkable speed and ease with which mental states cease and equanimity arises.
18193.sutta_1: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
18193.example_1: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

18152.meaning_1: just as quickly; as immediately as this
18152.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this word emphasizes the extreme speed and ease with which mental states arise and cease, highlighting the rapidity of the process described.
18152.sutta_1: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
18152.example_1: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

18139.meaning_1: just as easily; with as little difficulty as this
18139.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this adverb emphasizes the ease with which mental states cease and equanimity arises.
18139.sutta_1: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
18139.example_1: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

1043.meaning_1: a snap of the fingers; a sudden action
1043.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, "accharikaṃ" refers to the quick snapping of fingers as a simile for the rapid cessation of pleasant and unpleasant feelings.
1043.example_1: tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti. seyyathāpi, ānanda, balavā puriso appakasireneva accharaṃ [accharikaṃ] pahareyya, evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti, ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā sotaviññeyyesu saddesu.

13959.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The word describes the slightly concave surface of a lotus leaf where water droplets roll off without sticking, illustrating the concept of equanimity in the context.
13959.example_1: tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti. seyyathāpi, ānanda, īsakaṃpoṇe [īsakapoṇe, īsakaphaṇe, majjhe uccaṃ hutvāti ṭīkāya saṃsanditabbā] padumapalāse  [paduminipatte] udakaphusitāni pavattanti, na saṇṭhanti, evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti, ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā ghānaviññeyyesu gandhesu.

61752.meaning_1: should be compared (with); should be in agreement (with)
61752.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the commentary suggests that the ṭīkā (sub-commentary) should be compared/agreed with the main text.
61752.example_1: tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti. seyyathāpi, ānanda, īsakaṃpoṇe [īsakapoṇe, īsakaphaṇe, majjhe uccaṃ hutvāti ṭīkāya saṃsanditabbā] padumapalāse  [paduminipatte] udakaphusitāni pavattanti, na saṇṭhanti, evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti, ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā ghānaviññeyyesu gandhesu.

42191.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence illustrates the non-stick quality of lotus leaves, where water droplets roll off without adhering to the surface.
42191.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, ānanda, īsakampoṇe padumapalāse udakaphusitāni pavattanti, na saṇṭhanti;
42191.example_1: It’s like how a drop of water would roll off a gently sloping lotus leaf, and would not stay there.

42195.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, it refers to water droplets rolling off a lotus leaf without sticking, illustrating the concept of equanimity.
42195.example_1: tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti. seyyathāpi, ānanda, īsakaṃpoṇe [īsakapoṇe, īsakaphaṇe, majjhe uccaṃ hutvāti ṭīkāya saṃsanditabbā] padumapalāse  [paduminipatte] udakaphusitāni pavattanti, na saṇṭhanti, evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti, ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā ghānaviññeyyesu gandhesu.

15990.meaning_1: Section 3 of the Majjhima Nikāya; Later Fifty Suttas
15990.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
Refers to the third division of the Majjhima Nikāya, containing suttas 101-152. The contextual sentence shows its usage in reference to completing this section.

41678.construction:
pañca + dasa + ā + ka
paṇṇāsā + ka
41678.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, "tīhi paṇṇāsakehi paṭimaṇḍito sakalo" refers to the entire collection being adorned with three groups of fifty suttas each.

24673.meaning_1: Chapter 6 of the Majjhima Nikāya; Chapter on Householders (MN51-60)
24673.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this is the first chapter (paṭhamo) of the Majjhima Nikāya dealing with householders, containing suttas MN51-60.
